FacilityName: Tyson Foods, Inc. Council Bluffs, IA

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
1.  Accident Release Prevention Program and Emergency Response Policy
It is the policy of the Tyson Foods, inc. (Tyson Foods) Council Bluffs, Iowa facility management to implement the requirements of this Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68 and with the corresponding regulations under OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) program.  The objective is to minimize the risk of a release of a hazardous material and if a release occurs, to minimize the potential impact to Tyson Foods employees, the public and the environment.  This objective will be accomplished by utilizing general good operating procedures, providing appropriate training to all employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary, with the local emergency response providers.  This plan covers all Tyson Foods owned activities at this facility.
Tyson Foods management is committed to providing the resources necessary to implement this policy.

2.  Facility Description
Tyson Foods operates two meat processing plants at this facility location.  Various meat cuts are trucked to the plants and processed into both raw and cooked meat products.  Support operations include cold storage and administrative offices.
One chemical is utilized at the facility in sufficient quantities to be subject to the requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.  This chemical is ammonia and is used as a refrigerant throughout the facility.

3.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
The Council Bluffs, Iowa facility is governed by a set of OSHA and USEPA regulations that require planning and facility activities intended to prevent a release of hazardous material, or if a release inadvertently occurs, to minimize the consequences of a release to the employees of the facility, the public and to the environment.  These regulations include:
* 40 CFR Part 68, Accidental Release Prevention
* 40 CFR Part 112, Spill Preventio

n, Control and Countermeasure
* 40 CFR Part 264, Hazardous Waste Contingency Plan
* 29 CFR Part 119, Process Safety Management
* 40 CFR Part 302, Emergency Planning and Community Right-to-Know Act (EPCRA)
The key concepts in Tyson Foods's release prevention program are employee participation, appropriate design and maintenance of equipment, and appropriate training of all employees.  Tyson Foods has developed and documented these elements in their process safety management plan (PSM).  The PSM plan is incorporated with this document by reference.
Employee participation in the release prevention program is encouraged and supported by Tyson Foods management.  Key personnel are responsible for conducting and implementing the findings from the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) for the ammonia systems.  Tyson Foods employees are also members of the facility emergency response team.
Tyson Foods policy is to construct all new equipment, systems, and facilities to ensure the appropriate safety and release prevention systems are included from the beginning of each project.  Tyson Foods maintains a computerized program of maintenance activities to ensure that key systems are maintained appropriately to minimize the risk of a release.
Tyson Foods is committed to providing appropriate training to all employees regarding safety procedures.  Each new employee is provided comprehensive safety training during their initial orientation for the facility.  In addition, Tyson Foods conducts regularly scheduled safety training for all employees each year.  Additional training is provided to maintenance personnel for the systems they are responsible for.

4.  Five Year Accident History
Tyson Foods has not had a release of ammonia from the Council Bluffs, Iowa facility during this period that has affected the public or the environment.

5.  Emergency Response Program
Tyson Foods personnel will provide access to the facility to the Council Bluffs Fire Department in the event of an incident req

uiring off-site response.  Tyson Foods personnel may assist the Council Bluffs Fire Department in a non-responding capacity.

6.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Tyson Foods completes a thorough review of the ammonia systems each time a design change is implemented.  Tyson Foods is committed to using these methods to identify and implement ways to improve the safety of these systems.
